articles.headline: G.M. Hires Finance Chief From Microsoft
articles.snippet: Christopher Liddell helped cut costs at Microsoft, and with his new role as G.M.’s finance chief, he might be in the running for the top job at the automaker.
articles.abstract: Christopher Liddell helped cut costs at Microsoft, and with his new role as G.M.’s finance chief, he might be in the running for the top job at the automaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors’ chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., continued his hurry-up offense approach to remaking the automakers’ management ranks Monday, naming Christopher P. Liddell, who led a recent $3 billion cost-cutting effort at Microsoft, as its chief financial officer and a vice chairman.

articles.headline: The Science of Managing Search Ads
articles.snippet: More than a million businesses use Google’s search advertising system to attract customers, a strategy combining gamesmanship with frequent data analysis.
articles.abstract: More than a million businesses use Google’s search advertising system to attract customers, a strategy combining gamesmanship with frequent data analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Cyber Monday had gone swimmingly for Tiny Prints.

articles.headline: Desert Vistas vs. Solar Power
articles.snippet: Senator Dianne Feinstein introduced legislation to protect a million acres of the Mojave Desert in California by scuttling planned solar plants and wind farms.
articles.abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein introduced legislation to protect a million acres of the Mojave Desert in California by scuttling planned solar plants and wind farms.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMBOY, Calif.  Senator Dianne Feinstein introduced legislation in Congress on Monday to protect a million acres of the Mojave Desert in California by scuttling some 13 big solar plants and wind farms planned for the region.

articles.headline: It’s Tax Time for the Savvy and the Quick
articles.snippet: Consumers who have a strategy and know certain tax laws can save money if they act by Dec. 31.
articles.abstract: Consumers who have a strategy and know certain tax laws can save money if they act by Dec. 31.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the holidays in full swing, tax season seems like a long way off. But there are only 10 days left to lower your 2009 tax bill.

articles.headline: Efforts Lag to Improve Safety at Work Zones
articles.snippet: Through the indifference of government and industry, hundreds of people die each year in accidents in highway work zones.
articles.abstract: Through the indifference of government and industry, hundreds of people die each year in accidents in highway work zones.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Bryan Lee headed to work along Highway 51 in Texas on Sept. 15, 2005, the road-building industry and its government overseers were painfully aware of a deadly, though easily corrected, construction hazard: pavement-edge drop-offs.

articles.headline: Stiff Fines Are Set for Long Wait on the Tarmac
articles.snippet: Carriers that do not provide food and water after two hours or a chance to disembark after three hours will face penalties of $27,500 a passenger.
articles.abstract: Carriers that do not provide food and water after two hours or a chance to disembark after three hours will face penalties of $27,500 a passenger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The federal government will impose stiff penalties starting this spring on airlines that keep passengers waiting too long on the tarmac without feeding them or letting them off the plane  a remedy that will relieve many travelers but mean longer delays for a few.

articles.headline: Repaying U.S. and Reaping Bounty in Fees
articles.snippet: To repay taxpayers, Wall Street banks raised billions of dollars in new capital, and they generated millions of dollars in fees doing so.
articles.abstract: To repay taxpayers, Wall Street banks raised billions of dollars in new capital, and they generated millions of dollars in fees doing so.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here comes another payday on Wall Street, just in time for the holidays.

articles.headline: Tax Credit Gives a Lift to Housing
articles.snippet: A downward revision to 2.2 percent growth from 2.8 percent in the U.S. was partly because shoppers did not spend as much and construction was weaker than first thought.
articles.abstract: A downward revision to 2.2 percent growth from 2.8 percent in the U.S. was partly because shoppers did not spend as much and construction was weaker than first thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Data released on Tuesday indicated that the economic recovery, while still uneven, has carried into the end of the year, and analysts expect it to gain strength, a view seconded by investors.
